contentrichtext.text: {{Multiple issues |onesource = February 2009 |refimprove = February 2009 }} {{Infobox political party |country = Latvia |name_english = Socialist Party of Latvia |name_native = [[Latvian Language|Latvian]]:Latvijas Sociālistiskā partija<br>[[Russian Language|Russian]]: Социалистическая партия Латвии |colorcode = red |logo = [[File:Latvian Socialist Party logo.jpg]] |leader = [[Alfreds Rubiks|Alfrēds Rubiks]] |foundation = 1994 |ideology = [[Communism]]<ref name=pae>[http://www.parties-and-elections.de/latvia.html Parties-and-elections.de]</ref><br>[[Marxism–Leninism]]<br> '''Historical:''' <br> [[Russians in Latvia|Russian minority politics]] |position = [[Far-left politics|Far-left]]<ref name='march'>{{cite book |title=Contemporary Far Left Parties in Europe |last=March |first=Luke |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2008 |publisher=Friedrich-Ebert-Stiftung |location=Berlin |isbn=978-3-86872-000-6 |page=3 |pages= |url=http://library.fes.de/pdf-files/id/ipa/05818.pdf |accessdate=}}</ref> |international =[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union (2001)|Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] |european = ''None'' |europarl = [[European United Left–Nordic Green Left]] |colours = Red |headquarters = [[Riga]] |seats1_title = [[Saeima]] |seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|3|100|hex=#AD0005}} |seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] |seats2 = {{Infobox political party/seats|1|9|hex=#AD0005}} |website = [http://www.latsocpartija.lv http://www.latsocpartija.lv] }} The '''Socialist Party of Latvia''' ({{lang-lv|Latvijas Sociālistiskā partija}}, LSP, {{lang-ru|Социалистическая партия Латвии}}) was formed in 1994 as a successor party to the [[Communist Party of Latvia]], which was banned in 1991. In essence, the party is [[communist]];<ref name=pae /> according to the programme of the party, the LSP was founded as an organization upholding socialist ideas after the 1991 events that the party describes as a 'counter-revolutionary bourgeois-nationalist coup'.<ref>http://www.latsocpartija.lv/userfiles/LSP%20programma%202005%20RU%281%29.pdf</ref> The current president of the party is [[Alfrēds Rubiks]], once mayor of [[Riga]] and later leader of the unionist movement and head of the Latvian Communist Party (CPSU platform). He was imprisoned for six years in 1991 on charges of participating in a [[coup d'état]] against the Latvian authorities in August 1991. He is not one of the party's members in the [[Saeima]] (Latvian Parliament) since he is not allowed to contest elections. However, his son Artūrs Rubiks is a member of Saeima, representing the Socialist Party. The LSP is more popular among the [[Russian language|Russian-speaking]] population of Latvia. It places a high priority on issues important to ethnic [[Russians]], such as language and citizenship laws. The party also believes that Latvian citizenship should be granted to all citizens of USSR living in Latvia in 1990. This would entail a major change in the current law which only gives automatic citizenship to descendants of people who were citizens of the Republic of Latvia before it was [[Soviet occupation of Latvia in 1940|occupied]] by the Soviet Union in 1940 and requires the Soviet citizens who moved to Latvia between 1940 and 1990 (mainly Russians) to go through a [[naturalization]] process. In the [[elections in Latvia|election]], on 5 October 2002, the party was part of the [[For Human Rights in United Latvia]] ({{lang-lv|Par cilvēka tiesībām vienotā Latvijā}}) coalition that won 19.0% of the popular vote and 25 out of 100 seats. (5 of those seats went to Socialist Party.) The party was a member of this alliance of predominantly Russian-speaking parties from 1998 to 2003. Today, the party's platform is centered on anti-corruption and promoting an independent Latvia that is free from [[European Union|EU]] centralised power. In 2005, the LSP entered the "[[Harmony Centre]]" coalition, which won 17 seats in the 2006 election. 4 of these 17 parliament members are representatives of the Socialist Party. In 2011, HC won 31 seat, with socialists receiving 3 seats (Ar. Rubiks, R. Rubiks and I.
